Line 355: Line 355:
The same organisers of the "Day of Anger," "Friday of Anger," "March of the Millions" and "Friday of Departure" called for a protest in what was dubbed the "'''Day of Egypt's Love'''". ({{lang-ar|ÙÙÙ Ø­Ø¨ ÙØµØ±}}).<ref>{{ar}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/789346B3-1C7E-408F-8F8B-13A8207298C5.htm?wbc_purpose=Basic%2CBasic_Current|title=ÙØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª ÙÙÙÙÙÙØ© Ø¨ÙØµØ± ØªØµØ¹ÙØ¯ Ø§ÙØ¶ØºØ·|publisher=Aljazeera|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
The same organisers of the "Day of Anger," "Friday of Anger," "March of the Millions" and "Friday of Departure" called for a protest in what was dubbed the "'''Day of Egypt's Love'''". ({{lang-ar|ÙÙÙ Ø­Ø¨ ÙØµØ±}}).<ref>{{ar}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/789346B3-1C7E-408F-8F8B-13A8207298C5.htm?wbc_purpose=Basic%2CBasic_Current|title=ÙØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª ÙÙÙÙÙÙØ© Ø¨ÙØµØ± ØªØµØ¹ÙØ¯ Ø§ÙØ¶ØºØ·|publisher=Aljazeera|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
â
In one of the largest protests yet, over a million people gathered in and around Tahrir Square to demonstrate.<ref name="aljazeera3"/> Some people were reported to be joining the protests for the first time. At least 1,000 protesters went to the [[Egyptian Parliament|parliament]] to demand Mubarak's resignation. There was also a substantial protest in Alexandria,<ref name="aljazlive"/> and workers on the Suez Canal went on strike.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/5231/Egypt/Politics-/Suez-Canal-workers-go-on-strike-.aspx |title=Five Suez Canal companies workers go on strike, no major disruptions witnessed yet - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> BBC correspondents reported that by the afternoon the protests had the highest turnout to date.<ref>{{cite web|author=Yolande Knell |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12394941 |title=BBC News - Egypt protests: Hosni Mubarak's concessions rejected |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> Hundreds of journalists gathered in the lobby of the state-owned newspaper ''[[Al-Ahram]]''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s headquarters to protest against corruption and to call for greater freedom of the press.<ref name="NYT Strike">{{cite news|journal=New York Times|title=Protest in Egypt Takes a Turn as Workers Go on Strike|date=February 9|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/10/world/middleeast/10egypt.html|accessdate=February 9, 2011}}</ref>
+
In one of the largest protests yet, over a million people gathered in and around Tahrir Square to demonstrate.<ref name="aljazeera3"/> Some people were reported to be joining the protests for the first time. At least 1,000 protesters went to the [[Egyptian Parliament|parliament]] to demand Mubarak's resignation. There was also a substantial protest in Alexandria,<ref name="aljazbloglive8feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/07/live-blog-feb-8-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 8 – Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref> and workers on the Suez Canal went on strike.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/5231/Egypt/Politics-/Suez-Canal-workers-go-on-strike-.aspx |title=Five Suez Canal companies workers go on strike, no major disruptions witnessed yet - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> BBC correspondents reported that by the afternoon the protests had the highest turnout to date.<ref>{{cite web|author=Yolande Knell |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12394941 |title=BBC News - Egypt protests: Hosni Mubarak's concessions rejected |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> Hundreds of journalists gathered in the lobby of the state-owned newspaper ''[[Al-Ahram]]''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s headquarters to protest against corruption and to call for greater freedom of the press.<ref name="NYT Strike">{{cite news|journal=New York Times|title=Protest in Egypt Takes a Turn as Workers Go on Strike|date=February 9|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/10/world/middleeast/10egypt.html|accessdate=February 9, 2011}}</ref>
In a statement made on Egyptian state television, Omar Suleiman announced the formation of two independent committees for political and constitutional reforms, both starting work immediately. One committee would carry out constitutional and legislative amendments to enable a shift of power; while the other committee would monitor the implementation of all proposed reforms. Suleiman also stressed that demonstrators would not be prosecuted and that a separate independent fact-finding committee would be established to probe the violence of 2 February.<ref name="aljazeera4">{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201128123235508653.html |title=Protests swell at Tahrir Square
In a statement made on Egyptian state television, Omar Suleiman announced the formation of two independent committees for political and constitutional reforms, both starting work immediately. One committee would carry out constitutional and legislative amendments to enable a shift of power; while the other committee would monitor the implementation of all proposed reforms. Suleiman also stressed that demonstrators would not be prosecuted and that a separate independent fact-finding committee would be established to probe the violence of 2 February.<ref name="aljazeera4">{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201128123235508653.html |title=Protests swell at Tahrir Square
â
|publisher=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |date= 8 February 2011 |accessdate= 8 February 2011}}</ref> He said that wider press freedoms were under consideration and that he would produce a checklist of what was needed to hold free elections.<ref>{{cite web|last=Namatalla |first=Ahmed A |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-08/suleiman-to-meet-media-chiefs-in-bid-to-show-egypt-moving-on-press-freedom.html |title=Egyptians Rally in Cairo as Suleiman Pledges Change |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> He also said that plans were underway to organise a peaceful transfer of power.<ref name="aljazlive"/> Suleiman reiterated his view that Egypt is not ready for democracy, while also warning of a possible [[coup d'Ã©tat]] unless demonstrators agree to enter negotiations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110209/D9L9A7UO0.html |title=Egypt protesters defy VP warnings they must stop |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref>
+
|publisher=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |date= 8 February 2011 |accessdate= 8 February 2011}}</ref> He said that wider press freedoms were under consideration and that he would produce a checklist of what was needed to hold free elections.<ref>{{cite web|last=Namatalla |first=Ahmed A |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-08/suleiman-to-meet-media-chiefs-in-bid-to-show-egypt-moving-on-press-freedom.html |title=Egyptians Rally in Cairo as Suleiman Pledges Change |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> He also said that plans were underway to organise a peaceful transfer of power.<ref name="aljazbloglive8feb"/> Suleiman reiterated his view that Egypt is not ready for democracy, while also warning of a possible [[coup d'Ã©tat]] unless demonstrators agree to enter negotiations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110209/D9L9A7UO0.html |title=Egypt protesters defy VP warnings they must stop |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref>
Ibrahim Yosri, a lawyer and former deputy foreign minister, drafted a petition, along with 20 other lawyers, asking the Prosecutor General Abdel Meguid Mahmoud to try Mubarak and his family for stealing state wealth.<ref name="aljazeera4"/>
Ibrahim Yosri, a lawyer and former deputy foreign minister, drafted a petition, along with 20 other lawyers, asking the Prosecutor General Abdel Meguid Mahmoud to try Mubarak and his family for stealing state wealth.<ref name="aljazeera4"/>
